title: Boldness in Christ
shortSummary: Acts Chapter 4 recounts the early church's bold witness after the healing of a lame man, despite opposition from religious leaders. The apostles, filled with the Holy Spirit, proclaim salvation through Jesus Christ alone and demonstrate unity and generosity among believers. This chapter highlights the power of prayer, the courage to stand for the gospel, and the communal life of the early church.
timeline: c. AD 30-33 - Early Jerusalem Church after Pentecost

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of Jesus' apostles, filled with the Holy Spirit, who boldly proclaims Jesus Christ as the source of healing and salvation.

keyCharacters.name: John
keyCharacters.description: An apostle who, alongside Peter, witnesses the healing and boldly testifies before the Jewish council.

keyCharacters.name: Annas
keyCharacters.description: The high priest at the time, a leading figure among the Jewish religious authorities confronting the apostles.

keyCharacters.name: Caiaphas
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who, along with Annas and other leaders, questions Peter and John about their authority to heal and preach.

keyCharacters.name: Barnabas
keyCharacters.description: Also called Joses, a Levite from Cyprus who sells his land and donates the proceeds to support the apostles and the church.

definitions.definition: A Jewish sect known for denying the resurrection of the dead and opposing the apostles' teaching about Jesus' resurrection.
The third Person of the Trinity, who empowers believers for bold witness and spiritual service.
A metaphor referring to Jesus as the cornerstone of the spiritual building, rejected by men but chosen by God.
A man lame from birth who was miraculously healed by the apostles in the name of Jesus Christ.

outline.heading: Arrest and Examination of Peter and John
outline.description: Peter and John are arrested by the priests and Sadducees for preaching about Jesus' resurrection and healing a lame man. The next day, they are questioned by the Jewish rulers about the source of their authority.

outline.heading: Peter’s Bold Defense
outline.description: Filled with the Holy Spirit, Peter boldly proclaims that the healing was done by the name of Jesus Christ, whom the rulers crucified but God raised from the dead. He declares that salvation is found in no other name.

outline.heading: Council’s Threat and Apostles’ Obedience to God
outline.description: The rulers marvel at the apostles’ boldness but threaten them to stop preaching in Jesus’ name. Peter and John respond that they must obey God rather than men, and they are released due to the people’s praise of God.

outline.heading: Prayer for Boldness and Empowerment
outline.description: The believers pray together, acknowledging God’s sovereignty and asking for boldness to continue preaching. The place shakes, and they are filled with the Holy Spirit, enabling them to speak God’s word with courage.

outline.heading: Unity and Generosity Among Believers
outline.description: The early church lives in unity, sharing possessions so that no one lacks. Barnabas sells land and gives the proceeds to the apostles, exemplifying the spirit of generosity.

application: Trust in the power of the Holy Spirit to give boldness when sharing your faith, even in the face of opposition.
Obey God rather than men when commands conflict with the gospel, standing firm in the truth of Jesus Christ.
Pray corporately with other believers, seeking God’s guidance, empowerment, and unity for the advancement of His kingdom.
Practice generosity and care for fellow believers, reflecting the early church’s example of sharing resources to meet needs.

keyVerses.text: Neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the exclusive nature of salvation through Jesus Christ, central to the Christian faith.

keyVerses.text: But Peter and John answered and said unto them, Whether it be right in the sight of God to hearken unto you more than unto God, judge ye.
keyVerses.significance: Peter’s declaration highlights the priority of obeying God over human authorities when they conflict.

keyVerses.text: And when they had prayed, the place was shaken where they were assembled together; and they were all filled with the Holy Ghost, and they spake the word of God with boldness.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the powerful response of God to united prayer and the resulting boldness in witness.
